awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Two-Phase Microchannel Heat Sink with Porous Layers Lining Channel Inner Walls
awd_abstract_narration:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will develop an advanced two-phase micro/mini-channel heat sink that can remove high heat fluxes with reduced instabilities and achieve more uniform temperatures than the current state of-the-art two-phase heat sinks. The proposed concept will potentially improve the scalability, reliability, and versatility of two-phase micro/mini-channel heat sinks by addressing two key issues: parallel channel instabilities and transient dryout of channels experiencing vapor explosion. The specific feature in the proposed concept is a porous layer lining the heat sink walls. The porous layer provides more uniform nucleation during flow boiling and also stores liquid for evaporation during the bubble venting period, resulting in improved temperature uniformity and reduced flow and temperature oscillations. There are three objectives for the Phase I project: (1) develop a model to select the most favorable porous layer and heat sink geometries; (2) optimize the techniques for porous layer manufacturing and characterization; and (3) build and test microchannel heat sinks with porous layers to demonstrate their performances. The Phase II project will develop the advanced two-phase micro/mini-channel heat sinks for specific commercial and military applications for these partners.

Broader Impact of the Proposed Work and Commercialization Potential
The broader impact/commercial potential of this project will contribute to better understanding of two-phase micro/mini-channel instabilities and develop effective means to suppress them. The results of the project will improve micro/mini-channel heat sink usefulness and robustness for diverse operating conditions. This is a critical step towards commercialization of two-phase micro/mini-channel heat sinks. Mobile internet, assistive technologies, and other electronics technologies with market sectors in chip manufacturing, aging population, and transportation could benefit from the proposed technology. It was predicted that the total annual electricity savings in the U.S. alone could reach $1B if advanced chip level (liquid, two-phase, etc.) cooling solutions are implemented for computer data centers.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Two-Phase Microchannel Heat Sink with Porous Layers Lining Channel Inner Walls

This NSF Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project studied two different microporous coatings on two-phase heat sink channels to promote nucleate boiling and to suppress flow instabilities. A two-phase heat sink model was developed and used to optimize the heat sink geometrical parameters. Two different types of microporous coatings were developed and successfully deposited on the mini- and small-channel heat sink channels. A two-phase pumped loop test bed was also developed and used to test the heat sinks. This project demonstrated that the heat sinks with microporous coating operate with lower oscillations in the heat sink temperature and dissipate heat at lower heat sink thermal resistance than uncoated heat sinks. Some of the heat sinks with microporous coating were also demonstrated to operate at higher critical heat flux than the uncoated heat sinks. Adding the porous coating on the channel walls did not increase the pumping power or pressure drop through the heat sink. The Phase II project will develop a heat sink with microporous coating and a two-phase pumped loop for cooling high power devices including and large area laser arrays. Currently, single phase microchannel coolers are used in many of these technologies yet they are incapable of meeting the cooling requirements for the high power devices.

The broader impacts of this technology include an improved understanding of two-phase instabilities and the development of effective means to suppress them. This is a critical step in applying two-phase pumped technologies to electronics cooling for applications that require high heat flux and large area cooling. In addition, suppression of the instabilities and improved isothermality will improve the reliability and performance of high power electronic devices.  As mentioned, a cooler will be developed in Phase II for cooling high power lasers that are used in many medical therapy and diagnostics procedures including dermatology, ophthalmology, surgical procedures, prostate treatment and cosmetic treatments. Other applications include scientific research, communications, and material processing. Mobile internet, assistive technologies, and other electronics technologies with market sectors that include chip manufacturing, aging population, and transportation could benefit from the proposed technology. A university partner will participate in the Phase II program and aide in the development of the technology. By involving academic partners, the students will be given the opportunity to work on practical engineering and scientific problems and be better prepared to transition from academia to industry.


Last Modified: 01/14/2011
Modified by: Tadej Semenic

Images (1 of )
